questions.text: Which type of memory is volatile?
questions.explanation: RAM (Random Access Memory) is volatile memory, meaning it loses its data when power is removed.

questions.text: What is the purpose of ROM?
questions.explanation: ROM (Read-Only Memory) is non-volatile memory used to store firmware and boot instructions.

questions.text: SSD is volatile memory.
questions.explanation: SSD (Solid State Drive) is non-volatile memory.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of SRAM?
questions.explanation: SRAM (Static RAM) is faster and more expensive than DRAM.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of DRAM?
questions.explanation: DRAM (Dynamic RAM) requires periodic refreshing to maintain its data.

questions.text: Cache memory is slower than RAM.
questions.explanation: Cache memory is faster than RAM.

questions.text: What is the purpose of memory addressing?
questions.explanation: Memory addressing is used to locate specific memory locations.

questions.text: What is memory segmentation?
questions.explanation: Memory segmentation is a memory management technique that divides memory into logical segments.

questions.text: Memory paging is a hardware-based memory management technique.
questions.explanation: Memory paging can be implemented in hardware or software.

questions.text: Which of the following is a benefit of using virtual memory?
questions.explanation: Virtual memory allows programs to use more memory than is physically available.
correctAnswers: Use more memory than physically available

questions.text: What is the purpose of a memory management unit (MMU)?
questions.explanation: A memory management unit (MMU) manages memory access and provides virtual memory capabilities.

questions.text: Memory fragmentation can lead to inefficient memory usage.
questions.explanation: Memory fragmentation can lead to inefficient memory usage.

questions.text: Which of the following is a technique for reducing memory fragmentation?
questions.explanation: Compaction is a technique for reducing memory fragmentation by moving allocated blocks of memory to one end of the memory space.

questions.text: What is the purpose of a page table?
questions.explanation: A page table maps virtual addresses to physical addresses.

questions.text: A TLB (Translation Lookaside Buffer) is a cache for page table entries.
questions.explanation: A TLB (Translation Lookaside Buffer) is a cache for page table entries.

questions.text: Which of the following is a benefit of using a TLB?
questions.explanation: A TLB reduces the time it takes to access memory by caching page table entries.

questions.text: What is the purpose of memory protection?
questions.explanation: Memory protection prevents unauthorized access to memory.

questions.text: Memory leaks can lead to system instability.
questions.explanation: Memory leaks can lead to system instability by consuming available memory.

questions.text: Which of the following is a technique for detecting memory leaks?
questions.explanation: Memory profiling is a technique for detecting memory leaks by monitoring memory allocation and deallocation.

questions.text: What is the purpose of memory alignment?
questions.explanation: Memory alignment improves memory access performance by ensuring that data is stored at addresses that are multiples of its size.

questions.text: Which type of storage is directly accessible to the CPU?
questions.explanation: Primary storage, often referred to as Memory or RAM, is the only type of memory directly accessible to the CPU.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered secondary storage?
questions.explanation: Secondary storage is 'non-volatile' memory storage; basically any storage that is not Primary is Secondary. Hard-disk Drives (HDDs), Solid-state Drives (SSDs), and any kind of external storage technologies (USB drives, floppy disks, magnetic tape, etc)

questions.text: What is the purpose of memory paging?
questions.explanation: Memory Paging - When RAM is full, these will act as a form of virtual memory Utilizes least-used chunks of secondary storage to increase the capacity of primary storage, albeit at the cost of performance.
correctAnswers: Increase the capacity of primary storage
wrongAnswers: Increase the speed of primary storage
Decrease the capacity of secondary storage
Decrease the speed of secondary storage

questions.text: What is the function of a device driver?
questions.explanation: Device Drivers - Computer programs that operate or control a particular type of device that is attached to a system. Provides a software interface to hardware devices, enabling operating systems and other computer programs to access hardware functions.
correctAnswers: Enables operating systems to access hardware functions
